0.13.text:
>> Male presenter: Best thing about Matt's

4.00.text:
So it's one of those stories that, when the
next time the world is beating you down and

8.25.text:
you're facing a challenge that you don't think

12.32.text:
you to get from the long journey from 'I can't
and I won't' to 'I will'.

18.84.text:

Expo at the Javits Center but he's here talking
to us today.

27.83.text: So let's give him a warm Google welcome.

30.64.text:
Ladies and gentlemen, fellow Googlers, Matt

So, if we took all the blood out of his body,

how much blood he lost in about ten, eleven

97.15.text:

108.02.text: >> Presenter: Matt, thanks so much for coming.

It's great to have you here at authors at

For those of you who don't know, this is the

So, for those of you who don't know your story

131.75.text:
room do, but maybe some folks will be seeing

135.75.text:
-- tell us about those terrible events that

143.06.text:
>> Matt: Well, if you lived in New York in

150.95.text:

when the city is at its peak for tourists

157.81.text: and just people shopping and the like.

162.28.text: But the transit authority went on strike.

166.64.text:
>> Matt: It was day three of the transit strike
and ironically my last day at my detail at

174.86.text: So I had no way to get to work.

178.37.text:
Actually, I could have gotten to work but
I couldn't get home if the strike didn't end.

186.37.text: I got four blocks from my New York City apartment.

189.02.text:
And a private bus that was hired to bring
their workers down below the restrictions

194.10.text:
that the mayor put in place an illegal right

203.27.text:
Whenever I tell people I was run over by a
bus.

210.83.text:
" I said, "Look believe it or not, for some

215.64.text: I was taken under the chassis of the bus

You've probably heard this story a million

and the doctor said you were losing four,

267.87.text:
>> Matt: One of the interesting things about

272.01.text:
I think the mind is just incredibly powerful
thing and as soon as I got hit, I don't remember.

277.32.text:
>>Presenter: You don't remember any of this,

279.08.text:
>>Matt: I don't remember any of it because
I think the mind said, "listen if this guy

281.09.text:
is going to survive, he doesn't need to have

287.50.text:
So I've gotten told all these stories from

292.42.text:
And one of the stories while I was under the
bus and the police from the ESU and the rescue

299.10.text:
fire department guys were trying to lift the
bus and get me out.

304.50.text:
They were having such a hard time doing it
because of my blood.

307.32.text:
They were slipping and sliding on my blood
on the street.

310.94.text:
One of the police officers totally broke protocol
and reached into my thigh and held my femoral

319.56.text: artery shut because it was severed.

321.56.text:
And he needed to slow the bleeding down and
he did it with his bare hand which was total

326.10.text:
no no in emergency service protocol; you know
we just don't do that anymore.

333.33.text: You have to take care of yourself.

336.77.text:
>>Matt: That was the first step of saving
my life, for sure.

>> Presenter: Prior to the accident, you're

344.85.text:

348.80.text: get to do who take to marathon running.

353.48.text:
So another thing that probably saved your

360.45.text:
>>Matt: I remember my mom telling me the doctors

365.58.text:
That would be the worst part about being trauma

370.01.text:
the family the person you're working on may
not make it through the night.

375.59.text:
My mom was told that, the doctors basically

382.63.text: And my mom said, "Doc, you don't understand.

387.12.text: He just qualified for Boston marathon.

389.64.text:
[laughter] So I think it's that Irish Catholic

392.96.text: "No, no, no, he's not going anywhere."

395.97.text:
And it was that stubbornness, --whether you

401.59.text: And the doctor said, flat out, once he realized--.

402.60.text: He was a runner, too, my trauma surgeon.

404.72.text:
Once he realized that I was that fit to do

410.59.text:
Then maybe there's a better chance that he

>> Presenter: So this was a real tough time

They kept by your bedside and saw you through

My family -- there was constantly a family

[laughter] I have an ego they said when they

>> Matt: My family jokes about it now because

460.34.text: I wasn't eating food for two.

So Monday through Friday, you got chicken

What's the first thing that happened when

My first memory was my brother, Jim, coming

by a bus and I kind of looked at him like

And I was in the bed and I had a stabilizer,

They were just like, "You're going to be here

584.58.text:

640.70.text:

646.99.text:
It was kind of -- you know, I remember like

673.16.text:
When they came to sign the release I wrote

And the nurse was like, "No, no that's not

This is the release for what we hope will

689.84.text:
And this is the worst case scenario, what

I'd feel another hose or connection to my

700.43.text: So I got to come back.

707.26.text:
So just to be the able to walk and be released

I was on those Canadian crutches you saw in

group or something along those lines and then

And I was only out of the hospital--, it's

And I just thought it would be good to show

>> Matt: You know, probably -- obviously,

not a happy person and no one was really faulting

But it wasn't until I got home and there was

902.01.text: >> Presenter: And who brought you out of it.

905.86.text:
I went in for a doctor's appointment and you
know at this point in my life I was making

913.23.text: I was constantly just fix this.

916.50.text:
Just take care of this and I'll deal with
the limp and I'll deal with a cane.

921.45.text: Just give me this one thing.

923.55.text:
And when I went to this doctor's appointment
the doctor said to me, "Mr. Long I don't think

928.02.text: we're going to be able to help you.

932.27.text:
You just had too much muscle damage and nerve

937.91.text: And I just talked to my mom and dad.

941.48.text:
Listen I'm so glad that you guys prayed for

947.38.text:
But I wish you would have prayed for me to
die.

951.02.text:
>>Presenter: That must be so hard for a mom

955.52.text:
>> Matt: You never want to say that to your

961.05.text:
And I expected her to reach across the table
and hug me, you know "This is when you hug

964.38.text: me; I need you right now".

965.38.text:
I'm hitting the button for the nurse; hey,
where's the nurse And she just put her hands

969.87.text: down on the table and said, "enough is enough."

974.32.text:
She said, "you know, you have to think about
all the things you've done before this accident

979.75.text:
and you need to pick up the pieces and live
your life the best you can."

>> Presenter: It's tough love at a time when

987.59.text:
>> Matt: I was just like, you know, I was

992.92.text:
She just basically said if you're going to

And you went through a lengthy additional

This is a guy who could run a marathon in

1032.59.text:
>>Matt: What really happened is I didn't say

1037.88.text: I started to say I will be an athlete again.

1040.43.text:
That's when the training kicked in and I went
to Arizona.

1046.32.text:
I wanted to get away from New York, that was
the first thing.

1048.53.text: Mentally, I need to be out of here.

1049.76.text: I talked to my friend, Frank Carino.

1050.92.text: I talked to my friend, Noel Flynn.

1052.66.text: I was like, "I hope you guys don't mind.

1054.45.text:
I hope this isn't like I'm bailing out on
my support system, but I need a change in

1060.63.text: I need to forget about everything.

1062.08.text: Even the homeless guy outside Starbucks.

1063.85.text:
When I'd walk with my crutches, he'd say "hey
you're the bus guy".

1067.09.text: And I was like everyone knows me.

1070.27.text: I need to get out of New York.

1073.65.text: >> Matt: And the sunshine helps, yeah.

1074.71.text: So I e-mailed a couple of warm weather facilities.

1077.62.text:
A couple people e-mailed me back saying amazing
story; you've been through so much.

1084.13.text:
We'd help you but you should have realistic
expectations.

1088.43.text:
And I was like, "how can this person tell
me to have a realistic expectation without

1094.35.text: even seeing me or knowing me."

1096.18.text: So I was just delete, delete.

1100.14.text: And then I found via Google.

1104.66.text: How else would you search the web.

1107.89.text:
I found the place called the Functional Performance
Center in Tempe.

1112.06.text:
Smaller than this room and a young guy who
went to Iowa.

1116.24.text: Either Iowa or Iowa State, I'm not sure.

1122.14.text:
He said, "First of all, I would never tell
anyone they couldn't run again."

1124.34.text:
>>Presenter: And that's what you needed to
hear, I'm sure.

1126.14.text: >>Matt: I moved down there three days later.

1127.55.text:
>>Presenter: Wow
>>Matt: Frank Carino had just had his second

1131.97.text: I haven't flown since my accident.

1133.83.text: I don't know what to expect.

1137.83.text: And I lived there three months.

1141.01.text:
The first day I said how is all this going
to help me run.

1144.19.text:
He said well, let's strengthen your body and
one day we're just gonna do it.

1147.91.text:
After three months, I went in and they were
like "let's go; today's the day".

1154.98.text:
>>Presenter: Probably scared you were going
to topple right over.

1158.83.text: It was like oh, you didn't prep me for this.

1162.38.text:
Last night I could have been thinking about

1165.68.text:
If you're doing an endurance race, the night
before you visualize your race.

1170.67.text: How am I gonna fix it.

1171.90.text: I didn't have any visualization for a mile.

1175.92.text: We did it in 18 minutes, 24 seconds I think.

1180.49.text:
And we stopped at the half mile turn around
point.

1185.26.text:
Then we tried to work on my gait a little
more.

1188.84.text: When I finished, we went into therapy.

1190.82.text:
>>Presenter: So, in a lot of ways, the same

1196.11.text:
athlete the first time around, you had to
learn it a second time, really.

>> Matt: Yeah, I dig the mechanics of running

When was the last time you got out of your
chair and thought about walking?

1214.05.text: And I had to do that.

1215.08.text: I had to think about even taking a step.

>> Presenter: So now you've completed one
step in your recovery.

1223.75.text:
You've actually successfully gone for a run,

1227.07.text:
Now, you tell your doctors I want to run in

1231.77.text:
>> Matt: One doctor said I'm crazy but then

1236.10.text: [laughter] Why would you want to run a marathon?

1241.13.text:
They didn't tell me not to try, but they said

1251.33.text: I needed it for my head.

1252.44.text: I needed it for the mental recovery.

1254.99.text:
You know, I just needed to see that finish
line to know that this was -- a part of my

1261.73.text:
life that will never, ever be behind me because
of how I am now but the come back is over.

1270.05.text: >> Presenter: You wanted your life back.

1271.05.text: >> Matt: I wanted my life back.

1272.05.text:
>> Presenter: And running, one of the biggest

1275.76.text:
the the biggest your past and your present
life.

1280.56.text:
>> Presenter: Tell us about marathon day when

1285.59.text:
>>Matt: My -- so I had the fire department
drive me to the start.

1289.11.text:
I got a 3 hour head start with the Achilles
Track Club.

1293.27.text:
I got a great story about the start of the
marathon.

1296.32.text:
They picked us up in a van, myself, Noel,
and Frank 'cause I had 2 buddies.

1300.66.text:
I figured 40,000 runners are going to be coming
from behind me.

1303.52.text:
Maybe I just need two people to make them
go wider.

1309.08.text: I mean Lance Armstrong had it.

1313.14.text:
[regular voice] I'm sorry [laughter] That's

1317.00.text: Later in the book we get to Lance

1320.62.text:
You got to meet Lance Armstrong after you
-- little bit after you -- about a year after

1326.68.text: Can you share that story real quick?

1330.39.text:
>>Matt: Obviously the marathon a big part
of my day.

1332.60.text: This weekend, the energy level is so great.

1334.84.text:
So the guys in the fire department thought
it would be great to take me to the 2006 start.

1341.06.text: I was still in a wheelchair part-time.

1343.08.text:
But I went with my crutches and Lance was
running.

1350.87.text:
And they got me to the start and they kept
tapping one of Lance's entourage on the shoulder

1360.90.text:
This guy got hurt on his bike; he got hit
by a bus".

1363.54.text: Lance had his sweat suit on.

1369.35.text: He's just getting tuned into the race.

1372.20.text:
Meanwhile all the pros are kind of on the
line in their shorts and tank tops freezing,

1376.47.text: but Lance had his swim jacket on.

1378.50.text:
Two minutes, Lance, and another piece came
off and he's getting ready.

1383.23.text: My boss is a big Italian guy.

1386.00.text:
He pushes on of Lance's guys and says "hey
Lance.

1390.05.text: [laughter] So he comes over to me.

1397.50.text:
[laughter] At that moment he was taking his
thing off, "what'd you say"?

1401.76.text: >>Presenter: So that really got his attention.

1404.16.text:
In his books and when people talk about him,

I do right now to make myself have a better

2795.29.text: And it could be the next water stop.

2796.84.text:
I'm going to get my cup of water and I'm going
to walk.

2799.59.text: You're not going to win the race, you know?

2802.70.text:
So five seconds instead of taking that paper
cup and splashing the water in your face and

2808.94.text:
getting just a couple drops and now you're
soaking wet, pull over to the side drink it

2813.18.text:
like a lady, [laughter] throw it in the garbage,
and run again.

2817.61.text:
Whatever it is at that moment to help yourself
have a better day do it and you'll just enjoy

2826.82.text: >> Male #3: Thanks very much for being here.

2830.22.text:
I'm curious -- this may be a bit technical
but you talk about having a change in mechanics.

2835.57.text:
The pictures suggest that there's a lot of
metal going on in your body.

2839.76.text:
[chuckles] How does it change the technique
and mechanics.

2843.09.text: What did you have to work on?

2844.17.text:
How is running that mile different today than
it was five years ago?

2849.45.text: >> Matt: So I said I have a leg length discrepancy.

2854.51.text: My legs are the same length, okay?

2857.03.text:
But my pelvis was shattered so badly that
the doctor the best they could do is kind

2861.44.text:
of like the right side is close to an inch
higher.

2865.35.text:
And there's like a 9-inch titanium screw that
holds that there.

2869.58.text:
I remember going he apologized he said if
it was a painting I wouldn't sign it.

2875.16.text: It's not my best pelvis repair.

2881.24.text:
He goes," but, I had the screw ready to drill
it in and you were dying.

2885.67.text: So do it now fix it."

2887.24.text: So I said okay I'm not upset, Doc, I'm here.

2890.79.text: So I have special shoes made.

2893.44.text:
So I, you know, it took me awhile to find
a running shoe company that would make it

2897.08.text:
for me but this company Zoot Sports, they're
a triathlon, multisport company.

2902.60.text: I sent them what I was doing.

2904.09.text:
Basically I was taking a running shoe to a
cobbler and he was putting a piece of rubber

2907.28.text:
on it that would make one shoe weigh about
2 pounds and the other shoe about 8 ounces.

2914.04.text:
With that lightweight foam whatever they built
an inch lift on a running shoe for me.

2919.85.text: So that helps that helps me stay level.

2922.76.text:
But as far as my muscle mechanics go, my right
side a lot of my stabilizer muscles and the

2928.67.text:
big muscle groups for running -- hamstring
-- they didn't come back to full strength.

2933.63.text:
So what I've learned is that, you know, the
body wants to be healthy.

2940.44.text:
You know, people talk about, "oh, I can never
do this.

2943.18.text:
Well, you probably have a bad back because
you're not active.

2946.79.text: You don't have, technically, a bad back.

2948.86.text:
Your back hurts when you get off the couch
because you're not treating your body right

2953.59.text: and your body wants to be healthy.

2955.29.text:
So when I was going through therapy in New
York with the performance guys, when I was

2959.67.text:
planning for the marathon they would tell
me, "Listen don't worry about your weakness

2964.02.text:
in this hamstring because the muscles around
it are going to pitch in because the body

2970.90.text:
I just had to talk to different muscles to
keep moving.

2974.54.text:
That's basically how I had to keep those mechanics
going.

2977.25.text: >> Presenter: Well, Matt, I know this is really.

2984.14.text: You don't want to go back to work do you?

2990.63.text:
I heard you speak at Ironman Lake Placid this
year when I was doing it.

2994.45.text: I had crashed my bike seven weeks beforehand.

2997.35.text: So I just want to kind of get your feeling.

2999.31.text:
I'm still really tentative on the bike from
the crash from the Half Ironman before Lake

3004.69.text:
How did you get your mind to go screaming
down key when you're worried about everything

3011.88.text: else and having been hit by the bus.

3014.10.text: How did you work your mind around that?

3019.58.text:
I that was the best part of the race 6 miles
downhill.

3022.16.text: I got my bike up to 50 miles an hour.

3025.43.text:
I can't do it in aero position like some people
do it.

3028.41.text: I hold on for dear life.

3032.05.text: I think it's like anything else.

3034.14.text:
You have to kind of think back to being a
kid.

3038.22.text:
And kids try everything, try anything, fall
down, get back up, do it again because they're

3044.82.text: So you have to try to lock that out.

3047.26.text:
Bring back that child inside you and say,
"granted you have to keep in mind the risk

3054.90.text:
I know a guy who's a phenomenal cyclist but
after he's married and has kids, he's on the

3058.67.text:
brakes that whole time and he used to just
fly down.

3063.53.text: You have to keep it realistic for yourself.

3066.85.text: Find that inner kid in you.

3070.32.text:
If this happened when I was 12, once the cast
is off, I'm back out there.

3074.62.text: So same kind of thing we have to do.

3076.39.text:
As we get older, recovery time is what we
don't have.

3079.89.text: That's why I don't try snow board.

3081.32.text:
I remember trying to snow board and I fell
like six times.

3084.06.text: The next day I was like I can't move.

3087.54.text: I just learned how to ski.

3090.56.text: As you get older, you can't recover as fast.

3094.56.text:
Find that inner child in you get rid of that
fear.

3099.89.text:
>> Female #2: I'm wondering how you view yourself
now versus how you thoughtful yourself before

3108.57.text:
You know, we all have a pretty good sense
of ourselves.

3112.06.text:
And then, when something like that happens,
your spirit's broken and you know, that's

3116.80.text: why you went through that phase.

3119.53.text:
And some of the things that define us before
something like that happens and they're taken

3124.14.text:
away from us causes us to think differently
of ourselves afterwards.

3127.77.text: How do you view yourself now?

3130.72.text:
>>Matt: As Mr. Murphy said, I have a little
bit of an ego.

3136.03.text:
[laughter] I was always a confident person
before the accident.

3141.75.text:
That 2-year journey where it was kind of sucked
out of me, I guess, without sounding too cocky,

3150.26.text:
you know, I realize that I'm tough son of
a bitch.

3159.18.text: I got that from my parents.

3161.31.text:
I was put through an awful lot and I wouldn't
want my worst enemy to go through what I went

3171.12.text:
But I know for a fact now that you don't do
things by yourself.

3176.10.text:
You know, if it wasn't for my mom and dad,
my brothers and sisters my fire department

3180.74.text:
friends and family, Vicky, Frank, and Noel,
the triathlete group that I trained with,

3186.37.text:
if it wasn't for that support group, I'm a
huge country fan.

3189.96.text:
Kenny Chesney has a song, I didn't get here
alone.

3193.37.text: I didn't get to this point alone.

3196.15.text:
I know that now more than ever that I relied
on those people and those friendships to get

3201.39.text:
And to make this recovery and this comeback
possible.

3204.86.text: But I'm still tough son of a bitch.

3210.63.text:
[chuckles] Well, Matt, your story has been
tremendously inspirational to me personally

3216.90.text:
and to a lot of the folks here at the Google
New York City office.

3220.53.text:
I know this was a busy week for you with the
New York City marathon being Sunday.

3223.58.text:
So for you to take some time out of your schedule,
we really appreciate it.

3227.14.text: Thanks so much for coming back.
